IT IS just a little over sixty years
since the death of Johns Hopkins,
Baltimore merchant prince and friend
of young men. I call him the friend
of young men because the appellation
is perfectly true and because it has
a present pathetic significance which
inspires this article.
There is nothing in the will of Johns
Hopkins which can be wrenched into
the meaning that he desired the undergraduate departments of his university neglected for the benefit of
the higher schools. And yet this is
what is actually taking place, at least
in one of the colleges at Homewood.
I have contacts at the University
which enable me to observe the undercurrents of change which flow
through that institution, to observe
the attitude both of students and faculty; and I cannot help feeling disheartened at what is revealed to me.

THERE IS said to be little college
spirit at Hopkins. No one who is familiar with the campus will deny this
accusation, least of all the students
themselves. The explanation of this

He will find also an encouraging atmosphere that will inspire him to do
his share, and a general feeling, to
which he will contribute, that the College of Arts and Sciences is just as
important as The School of Higher
Studies. Some of the progressive
members of the Board of Trustees
have stated that the future of the
University rests upon the undergraduate schools.
I DO NOT intend this as a destructive personal criticism. The whole
matter is the fault of no one individual. He who casts aspersions upon the
individual members of the Hopkins
faculty needs to guard himself against
the just resentment of the entire
country through which the reputation and renown of the University has
spread. But I do desire to register a
plea to hasten a better contact with
the young man in his teens upon
whom the problems of the future rest,
whether he prepares for a Ph.D. or
not. At present Hopkins is topheavy
with snobbish emphasis on research.
Cooperation is needed by everyone to
hasten the growth of the New Spirit.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 11, 1935.

Jay Swimmers CHEM. POISON
Face Lafayette
Here Tomorrow
Clash To Take Place At
Knights Of Columbus Pool
In The Alcazar Building

Meet Begins At8P.M.
Jays Hold Victory Over Local Y. M. H. A.; Will
Boast A Veteran Squad
Inaugurating their season against
one of the strongest teams to be met
this year, the Johns Hopkins swimming team will encounter Lafayette
in a home contest this Saturday. The
meet will be held at the Knights of
Columbus pool with the starting gun
sounding at 8 P. M.
Hambleton's
Coach

potentially

strong aggregation has been handicapped greatly by lack of practice,
as the members of the team have had
only one week of training for the
opening fray. This was due to the
difficulty in finding a natatorium suitable for the conditioning of a large
squad. The problem was finally met
by taking out part time memberships
at the Y. M. H. A., where the swimmers at present meet every day.
Training Hard
The natators have been working
hard for the past week, aided in their
training by a meet with the Y. M. H.
A. squad last Tuesday.
The Jays
captured the match handily, winning
by the score of 39-31 without using
Capt. Woody White, Louis and Buddy Adler, or Eddie Scheer. White and
Scheer were unable to compete due
to illness and lack of condition, while
the Adler brothers were held back by
A. A. U. complications.
Dan Weiner, sophomore backstroker, succeeded in breaking the pool
record in the 50-yard backstroke, negotiating the distance in 32 seconds.
Weiner and John Macgill, veteran
dorsal swimmers, are sure to score
well in their specialty this Saturday.

With the Chemists as the strongest
team and the Historians and Psychologists playing a close second, the first
round of the graduate basketball
league is about half-way completed.
At 5 p. m. today there will be a
game between the Chemistry and
Psychology teams, which is expected
to prove rather exciting.
The graduate league is composed
of seven teams, including the Chemistry, Psychology, Engineering, History (Political Science, Political Economy, and History), Biology (Botany,
Biology, and Zoology), Romance Language, and Mathematics departments.
In the games that have already
been played, the scores have been
close and the playing hotly contested. It is expected that as the season
progresses the calibre of the play will
improve. Several men in the graduate school, coming from foreign
countries, are now participating in
the sport for the first time and are
deriving much enjoyment from it.
A volley ball league has been organized in the graduate school and
those departments wishing to enter
should drop a note in box 1215.
The standings to date in the basketball league are.

A badminton ladder tournament is
now in the process of completion and
will continue through the remainder
of the winter season. An entrance fee
of 50 cents will be required of the
contestants so as to help defray the
expense for birdies and to insure good
ones being used. Definite afternoons
are being set aside so that each person will be able to play one match a
week.
Along with badminton there will be
tumbling and apparatus classes which
will begin immediately after the exams and also continue through the
winter. Tumbling will be held every afternoon from 4:30 to 6 o'clock.
Apparatus classes will take place at
the same time on Wednesdays. During
this time instruction will be given
although participants are invited to
practice in the gym at any time.

Baer To Organize
Instruction Class
in Counselor Work

HIPPODROME
6 Days Only,Beginning Friday
The "KING OF JAZZ"

A meeting of those interested in
finding summer work as counselors
at camps will take place on Wednesday, January 16, at 4:15 p. m. in the
assembly room of Latrobe Hall. The
meeting will be held in conjunction
with plans for the formation of a
class which will meet weekly to train
students for counselor jobs.
The course of training is open to
any interested student, although
those who have gone to camps before
are especially urged to attend. The
course will cover all phases of camp
duties, including theory as well as
actual practice. The first details will
be given at the Wednesday meeting
at which time registration will take
place.
The class will be under the supervision of Reuben Baer. All the large
camps are being communicated with
and although there are no guarantees for jobs as yet, it is expected
that requests for counselors will be
forthcoming. If for any reason a student will be unable to attend the first
meeting of the class, he will please
notify Mr. Baer through his mail box.

Charlie Jones and Eddie Scheer
will compete with White in the 50
and 100, while Jones, Scheer, L. Adler, and White will be the probable
quartet in the 400-yard relay.
Bill Hazlett is looked for to tally
5 points for the Black and Blue in the
breaststroke, with Bishop and Thomas
competing for the other vacancy in
this event.
Good Divers
The diving will be handled by Koenig and Albers, a well-balanced pair,
who should hold up the Jay end ably.
These plungers scored eight markers
against the "Y", finishing first and
second, respectively.
In continuation of the custom inaugurated last season, a freshman
contest will be held in connection
with the varsity meet. The first-year
men face Friends School in what appears to be a close encounter. Outstanding among the freshmen are
Billy Goodman, backstroke; Vincenti,
a sprinter; and Moses, who swims the
breaststroke. The last two named are
former members of the Friends team,
and will find themselves pitted against
their mates tomorrow night.

Handball Tournament
Progressing Smoothly
Competition Keen In Five Ladder
Tourneys; Winners To Vie
On February 20
The handball tournament has been
progressing smoothly with S. Blumberg, J. A. Burton, B. Prager, J. E.
Krell, and G. Kostant at the head of
their ladders. The tournament will
officially close on February 20, at
which time the five remaining leaders of each ladder will participate
in an elimination contest.
The winners of the ladder tournaments will be given regular rewards
and will be eligible for the varsity
handball team. The varsity will be
selected on the basis of the results of
the elimination contest and it is
hoped that competition will be arranged for them against St. John's,
Loyola, Navy, as well as other teams
throughout the state.

IT IS just a little over sixty years
since the death of Johns Hopkins,
Baltimore merchant prince and friend
of young men. I call him the friend
of young men because the appellation
is perfectly true and because it has
a present pathetic significance which
inspires this article.
There is nothing in the will of Johns
Hopkins which can be wrenched into
the meaning that he desired the undergraduate departments of his university neglected for the benefit of
the higher schools. And yet this is
what is actually taking place, at least
in one of the colleges at Homewood.
I have contacts at the University
which enable me to observe the undercurrents of change which flow
through that institution, to observe
the attitude both of students and faculty; and I cannot help feeling disheartened at what is revealed to me.

spirit at Hopkins. No one who is familiar with the campus will deny this

He will find also an encouraging atmosphere that will inspire him to do
his share, and a general feeling, to
which he will contribute, that the College of Arts and Sciences is just as
important as The School of Higher
Studies. Some of the progressive
members of the Board of Trustees
have stated that the future of the
University rests upon the undergraduate schools.
I DO NOT intend this as a destructive personal criticism. The whole
matter is the fault of no one individual. He who casts aspersions upon the
individual members of the Hopkins
faculty needs to guard himself against
the just resentment of the entire
country through which the reputation and renown of the University has
spread. But I do desire to register a
plea to hasten a better contact with
the young man in his teens upon
whom the problems of the future rest,
whether he prepares for a Ph.D. or
not. At present Hopkins is topheavy
with snobbish emphasis on research.
Cooperation is needed by everyone to
hasten the growth of the New Spirit.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 11, 1935.

Jay Swimmers CHEM. POISON
Face Lafayette
Here Tomorrow
Clash To Take Place At
Knights Of Columbus Pool
In The Alcazar Building

Meet Begins At8P.M.
Jays Hold Victory Over Local Y. M. H. A.; Will
Boast A Veteran Squad
Inaugurating their season against
one of the strongest teams to be met
this year, the Johns Hopkins swimming team will encounter Lafayette
in a home contest this Saturday. The
meet will be held at the Knights of
Columbus pool with the starting gun
sounding at 8 P. M.
Hambleton's
Coach

potentially

strong aggregation has been handicapped greatly by lack of practice,
as the members of the team have had
only one week of training for the
opening fray. This was due to the
difficulty in finding a natatorium suitable for the conditioning of a large
squad. The problem was finally met
by taking out part time memberships
at the Y. M. H. A., where the swimmers at present meet every day.
Training Hard
The natators have been working
hard for the past week, aided in their
training by a meet with the Y. M. H.
A. squad last Tuesday.
The Jays
captured the match handily, winning
by the score of 39-31 without using
Capt. Woody White, Louis and Buddy Adler, or Eddie Scheer. White and
Scheer were unable to compete due
to illness and lack of condition, while
the Adler brothers were held back by
A. A. U. complications.
Dan Weiner, sophomore backstroker, succeeded in breaking the pool
record in the 50-yard backstroke, negotiating the distance in 32 seconds.
Weiner and John Macgill, veteran
dorsal swimmers, are sure to score
well in their specialty this Saturday.

With the Chemists as the strongest
team and the Historians and Psychologists playing a close second, the first
round of the graduate basketball
league is about half-way completed.
At 5 p. m. today there will be a
game between the Chemistry and
Psychology teams, which is expected
to prove rather exciting.
The graduate league is composed
of seven teams, including the Chemistry, Psychology, Engineering, History (Political Science, Political Economy, and History), Biology (Botany,
Biology, and Zoology), Romance Language, and Mathematics departments.
In the games that have already
been played, the scores have been
close and the playing hotly contested. It is expected that as the season
progresses the calibre of the play will
improve. Several men in the graduate school, coming from foreign
countries, are now participating in
the sport for the first time and are
deriving much enjoyment from it.
A volley ball league has been organized in the graduate school and
those departments wishing to enter
should drop a note in box 1215.
The standings to date in the basketball league are.

A badminton ladder tournament is
now in the process of completion and
will continue through the remainder
of the winter season. An entrance fee
of 50 cents will be required of the
contestants so as to help defray the
expense for birdies and to insure good
ones being used. Definite afternoons
are being set aside so that each person will be able to play one match a
week.
Along with badminton there will be
tumbling and apparatus classes which
will begin immediately after the exams and also continue through the
winter. Tumbling will be held every afternoon from 4:30 to 6 o'clock.
Apparatus classes will take place at
the same time on Wednesdays. During
this time instruction will be given
although participants are invited to
practice in the gym at any time.

Baer To Organize
Instruction Class
in Counselor Work

HIPPODROME
6 Days Only,Beginning Friday
The "KING OF JAZZ"

A meeting of those interested in
finding summer work as counselors
at camps will take place on Wednesday, January 16, at 4:15 p. m. in the
assembly room of Latrobe Hall. The
meeting will be held in conjunction
with plans for the formation of a
class which will meet weekly to train
students for counselor jobs.
The course of training is open to
any interested student, although
those who have gone to camps before
are especially urged to attend. The
course will cover all phases of camp
duties, including theory as well as
actual practice. The first details will
be given at the Wednesday meeting
at which time registration will take
place.
The class will be under the supervision of Reuben Baer. All the large
camps are being communicated with
and although there are no guarantees for jobs as yet, it is expected
that requests for counselors will be
forthcoming. If for any reason a student will be unable to attend the first
meeting of the class, he will please
notify Mr. Baer through his mail box.

Charlie Jones and Eddie Scheer
will compete with White in the 50
and 100, while Jones, Scheer, L. Adler, and White will be the probable
quartet in the 400-yard relay.
Bill Hazlett is looked for to tally
5 points for the Black and Blue in the
breaststroke, with Bishop and Thomas
competing for the other vacancy in
this event.
Good Divers
The diving will be handled by Koenig and Albers, a well-balanced pair,
who should hold up the Jay end ably.
These plungers scored eight markers
against the "Y", finishing first and
second, respectively.
In continuation of the custom inaugurated last season, a freshman
contest will be held in connection
with the varsity meet. The first-year
men face Friends School in what appears to be a close encounter. Outstanding among the freshmen are
Billy Goodman, backstroke; Vincenti,
a sprinter; and Moses, who swims the
breaststroke. The last two named are
former members of the Friends team,
and will find themselves pitted against
their mates tomorrow night.

Handball Tournament
Progressing Smoothly
Competition Keen In Five Ladder
Tourneys; Winners To Vie
On February 20
The handball tournament has been
progressing smoothly with S. Blumberg, J. A. Burton, B. Prager, J. E.
Krell, and G. Kostant at the head of
their ladders. The tournament will
officially close on February 20, at
which time the five remaining leaders of each ladder will participate
in an elimination contest.
The winners of the ladder tournaments will be given regular rewards
and will be eligible for the varsity
handball team. The varsity will be
selected on the basis of the results of
the elimination contest and it is
hoped that competition will be arranged for them against St. John's,
Loyola, Navy, as well as other teams
throughout the state.
